TikTok Begins Removing Universal Music Publishing Songs: TikTok and Universal Music Group (UMG) are intensifying their royalty dispute, with UMG beginning to remove its published songs from TikTok. This action follows the expiration of their licensing agreement on January 31, expanding the conflict beyond UMG-owned or distributed recordings to include a broader range of music. The disagreement centers on renewal terms, with UMG seeking fair compensation for artists and songwriters, protection against AI's harmful effects, and user safety on TikTok. UMG's vast catalog includes notable artists like Adele, Justin Bieber, and Taylor Swift, making the impact significant. TikTok counters UMG's claims by emphasizing its efforts to reach artist-first agreements with other labels and publishers. The standoff shows no signs of an immediate resolution, reminiscent of past disputes between music labels and platforms. The outcome could have a considerable impact on music promotion and royalties within the influencer marketing industry, affecting how content creators leverage music for engagement on TikTok. üëâüèº Read the full story by clicking here: https://lnkd.in/gFxxHcQs #InfluencerMarketing #Influencer #TikTok

Universal Music Group (UMG) has made a move that shook up the music scene on TikTok back in January. They decided to remove songs written or co-written by UMG artists from the platform, adding a new twist to the ongoing battle over music rights. This meant that some of your favorite tracks might have been missing from your TikTok videos as the platform complied with UMG's request. While this decision affected a wide range of artists, not just those signed with UMG, there were still plenty of tunes to groove to on TikTok. Why has Universal Music Group's catalog been removed from TikTok? Starting Febuary 1st, TikTok has removed Universal Music Group's catalog from its platform due to failed licensing talks between the two parties. The breakdown in negotiations occurred over three critical issues, according to UMG: ¬∑ Appropriate compensation for artists and songwriters ¬∑ Protection of human artists from the impact of AI ¬∑ Ensuring online safety for TikTok users. TikTok responded by stating that UMG prioritized greed over the interests of its artists and songwriters, asserting that the platform serves as a valuable promotional and discovery vehicle for talent. TikTok argued behind the scenes that it is not a music streaming platform and should not be licensed as such, pointing out that users cannot currently play full songs on the main TikTok platform. In an open letter, UMG accused TikTok of proposing significantly lower compensation rates for artists and songwriters compared to other major social platforms. UMG also raised concerns about TikTok allowing the platform to be flooded with AI-generated recordings and promoting AI music creation, potentially diluting the royalty pool for human artists. The dispute highlights the evolving landscape of digital platforms and the challenges in negotiating fair agreements between music rights holders and platforms like TikTok. The removal of UMG's extensive catalog, comprising approximately 3 million recorded music tracks and 4 million songs with UMG-represented publishing, is expected to have a significant impact on TikTok's music offerings. Some are saying this marks the end of music on Tiktok - do you agree? Universal Music Group pulling songs from Tik Tok serves as a lesson to the public about contract negotiations. As a summary, UMG distributes music from different artists, including popular artist like Taylor Swift and Drake. In order for UMG to distribute music to TikTok, there has to be a contract between UMG and TikTok. In this case, it's a licensing agreement. With the current agreement between the two parties expiring and no agreement on extending it or creating a new agreement, negotiations fell through. As a result, when the current agreement expired, videos that contained music featuring UMG artists had no audio. This situation is showing the public what goes on behind the scenes to make platforms like TikTok work. For TikTok to function as it currently does, lots of contracts are negotiated and executed. If these contracts fall through, users can be adversely affected. My thoughts? UMG was banking on the sentiments of TikTok users to gain leverage in negotiations. If audio from users' videos were removed or if users were not able use music in their future videos, then TikTok would come back to the negotiation table and be more amenable to the terms that UMG desired. As an entertainment lawyer, I think this is a good tactic. What are your thoughts? #umg #tiktok #music #socialmedia #contracts https://lnkd.in/eWz3tvqA

An informative analysis of the actions Universal has taken against TikTok. We are now just a few days away from March 1st, when additional 4 million songs will be removed from TikTok public library, if they do not reach a deal. They have already removed 3 million songs. The reason for these actions is to get paid more for music licensing. Universal is the globe's biggest music right holder. The unfortunate truth is that the biggest victims in these actions are emerging artists which have been growing momentum via TikTok. These actions also impact major artists like Taylor Swift, with her new release announced to be in April, the question is: how long can TikTok survive without music from the world's major artists? If you opened your TikTok this morning and noticed that some of your videos were silent, here‚Äôs why‚Ä¶ Many existing TikTok videos that feature UMG-published music have already had their audio muted. TikTok is motivated to do this because, now that UMG's licence agreement has expired. This means that every UMG song featured in a TikTok video may constitute a copyright violation On Tuesday, a day before its licencing contract with TikTok was set to expire, Universal published a fiery open letter accusing TikTok of providing inadequate payment for music and allowing its platform to be "flooded with A.I.-generated recordings" that diluted the royalty pool for real, human musicians. According to a TikTok source, the platform is not a music streaming platform and should not be licenced as such. Users on TikTok are unable to play whole songs and are limited to a maximum of 60 seconds of music in their videos. Does this mean that no music by UMG artists or songwriters can be heard in TikTok videos anymore? Well, not really. If you post on TikTok, you can choose music for your video from TikTok's song catalogue, which contains millions of tracks from record labels and independent artists who licence their music to TikTok for platform usage. That offering no longer includes UMG's catalogue. So say goodbye to finding your new favourite Drake lyric on TikTok. I'm more concerned about the musicians who are signed to the label but aren't marketed as much. TikTok viral challenges really played a major role in promoting their songs. But that‚Äôs just my opinion.
